description: From Latin chele, from Ancient Greek χηλή (khēlḗ).

entries.meaning: A pincer-like claw of a crustacean or arachnid. [from 17th c.]
examples: It happeneth often, I confess, that a lobster hath the chely or great claw of one side longer than the other  […]

entries.meaning: A pupil or disciple, especially in Hinduism. [from 19th c.]
examples: The guru had insight. He understood his chela. The relationship between a guru and his chela was as a father to a son, as a whole person to a whole person, individual and unique.
